title: Crate whose `dev-dependencies` depend on it produces confusing "is not implemented for" errors

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
Short explanation: If I have a crate `a` which has a dev dependency on crate `b`, which has a normal dependency on crate `a`, then `cargo test` in `a` can produce hard-to-understand errors.

# Full reproduction case (2 crates)

`a/Cargo.toml`:

```toml
[package]
name = "a"
version = "0.1.0"
edition = "2018"

[dev-dependencies]
b = { path = "../b" }
```

`a/src/lib.rs`:

```rust
pub trait Foo { fn foo(); }

#[test]
fn dep_impl() {
    <b::Bar as Foo>::foo();
}
```

`b/Cargo.toml`:

```toml
[package]
name = "b"
version = "0.1.0"
edition = "2018"

[dependencies]
a = { path = "../a" }
```

`b/src/lib.rs`:

```rust
pub struct Bar;
impl a::Foo for Bar { fn foo() {} }
```

# Output

The output of `cargo test` in `a/` is:

```
   Compiling a v0.1.0 (/home/jrvanwhy/cargo_test/a)
   Compiling b v0.1.0 (/home/jrvanwhy/cargo_test/b)
error[E0277]: the trait bound `b::Bar: Foo` is not satisfied
 --> src/lib.rs:5:5
  |
1 | pub trait Foo { fn foo(); }
  |                 --------- required by `Foo::foo`
...
5 |     <b::Bar as Foo>::foo();
  |     ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ the trait `Foo` is not implemented for `b::Bar`

error: aborting due to previous error

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0277`.
error: could not compile `a`.

To learn more, run the command again with --verbose.
```

This is confusing, because it is obvious that `b::Bar` implements `a::Foo`, yet the compiler tells you it doesn't.

My understanding is that the error occurs because there are two versions of `a`: `a` without `cfg(test)` and `a` with `cfg(test)`. `b` depends on `a` without `cfg(test)`, and implements that version of `Foo`, while `a`'s tests depend on the `cfg(test)` version of `Foo`.

I have confirmed this error message is the same in the latest stable and current nightly (`2021-02-25`) compilers.
